div1.p:
Recollections of Personal Experiences
In Connection With
Yellow Fever Epidemics in Havana
1898 - 1899 - 1900
(Dictated by Request)

Our Secretary, Mr. McLelland, has asked me to place
on record the recital I gave at a recent meeting of out Board
of Kirectors of episodes connected with Walter Reed and his inves-
tigations and discoveries with reference to yellow fever.

In November, 1898, after we had taken Santiago and
peace had been made, a Peace Commission, of which General Wade
was President for the United States and General Blanco for the
Spanish Government, was formed for the purpose of arranging the
details of transfer of the governmental authority from the Spanish
Crown to the United States Government. During the sittings of
this Commission, which commenced in August, an epidemic of yellow
fever broke out in Havana. Colonel Williams, of the United States
Army, and Colonel Waring, head of the Sanitary Department of New
York City, had been ordered to Havana to make preliminary provis-
ions of transfer, respectively, of everything pertaining to the
Quartermaster's Department and to sanitation.

In November these two officers, together with a large
number of their clerical force, died of yellow fever. I was or-
dered to Havana to take over the office of Colonel Williams and
another officer was ordered there to take up the work of Colonel
Waring. The second officer did not arrive, so when I reached
Havana in November I found myself at the head of the Quartermas-
ter's Department until the final withdrawal of our troops on the
twentieth of May, 1902.

There was much sickness at this period and great anx-
iety on account of the prevalence of yellow fever. Colonel
Williams and Colonel Waring had occupied an office jointly next
door to the Passaje Hotel on the Prado. Practically all the
clerks of both these offices met me on my arrival, with resignat-
ion in one hand and a request for transportation back to the
United States in the other. Of the few who remained, notably
Sergeant Merzig and Mr. Curry, I proceeded to build a new organ-
ization for both services.

As the colder weather came on, the yellow fever conditions
decreased in intensity and did not reappear again in epidemic form
until two years later, in 1900. In that year, symptoms of the epid-
emic appeared in Havana and various outlying centers, notably Pinar
del Rio, Guanajai, Vedado, Quemados and various military stations.
At this time I had become the Chief Quartermaster of the Depart-
ment of Cuba-- General Humphrey, my predecessor, having been or-
dered to duty in China. I occupied for my office the building
then known as the Segundo Cabo, facing the Plaza on which was loc-
ated the Governor General's Palace. In this same building were
located the offices of Chief Paymaster and Chief Commissary. In
a vacant room on the second floor of this building we organized
a small mess, where we served our luncheons. There were eight
people who were members of this mess, including my principal assis-
tant, Major George Cartwright, Major Matt Peterson, Chief Commiss-
ary Officer, Mrs. Peterson, his wife, Captain Page, and an aide-de-
camp to the Commanding General, Colonel Dodge, the Chief Paynaster,
Lieutenant Hanna, an aide-de-camp to the Commanding General, General
Wood.

The earliest deaths from yellow fever during this epidemic
occurred outside the limits of Havans, at Pinar del Rio and MarianaO.
The first of this group at mess to go down with yellow fever was
Major George Cartwright, my principal assistant, who died of the
disease. Sitting at his left was Major Peterson, who went down with
the disease and died. Mrs. Peterson was ill at the time and when
she was told by Major Gorgas that he feared she had contracted the
disease, she produced a pistol from her bag and shot herself. On
the next day, as I followed this double funeral to the last rest-
ing place, a carriage ahead of me turned out and I paused long
inough to speak with the occupant, Captain Page, who informed me
that he was so ill he could not proceed. I told him I would go on
to the funeral and as soon as I got back would get in touch with
him. Page occupied quarters at the top story of Segundo Cabo.
When I returned to my office I found him there, unable to climb the
stairs to his quarters, and with help I assisted him to his room
at the top of the building. Within forty-eight hours he died of
yellow fever. The next to be stricken with the disease was Colonel
Dodge, Chief Paymaster of the Department. Fortunately, he recovered
and later became Paymaster General of the Army. The nexp place at
the table was vacant as Lieutenant Hanna had taken a leave of absence,
returned to the United States, and later resigned his commission in
the Army. That left Captain E. C. Brooks and me looking across the
corner aof the table at on another.

At the advice of the surgeons, we had been in the habit of
serving a small quantity of red wine at luncheon. Someone of the
group, at the early inception of the epidemic, had proposed the
old English toast: “To those who are gone already and here's to
the next to go”. This toast was drunk daily until Brooks and I
were left looking across the corner of the table at one another.
Then, when he poured out a glass of wine, and pushed the decanter
to me, he lifted his glass and gave the toast. I remember saying:
“Brooks, I won't drink that toast to myself. You had yellow fever
in Santiago and are immune and won't have it again. Besides that,
you are a teetotaler and don't drink. So I'll drink my wine, but
not the toast”. He laughed and neither he nor I was stricken with
the disease.

During this same period, one after the other I placed five
men in charge of Major Cartwright's papers, which I was anxious
should be closed up as promptly as possible, especially in view of
the conditions that existed. In order to make sure that they
would be promptly closed and worked upon continuously, I set
aside a small room back of my own office and I assigned a clerk to
this special duty. The first that I placed in charge was Mr.
Ferguson, a civilian clerk, wupposed to be immune, having passed
through mor than one epidemic in New Orleans. Within twenty-four
hours after he took charge of the papers he come to me and said
he was too ill to go on. The next day he was dead of yellow fever.
One after the other, five men working on these papers went down
with yellow fever. The fifth man went down but fortunately recov-
ered and finished the papers.

About this time Major Gorgas came to me and asked me
to take his yellow fever ambulance (one that he had been using to
haul yellow fever patients) into the shops and overhaul it. He
assured me that there could not possibly be any contamination con-
nected with the ambulance and it could not possibly communicate
the disease. I explained to Gorgas that I would be very glad to
take the ambulance in and put it through the shops, and had no mis-
givings in regard to the communication of the disease, but I fear-
ed for the morale of the men working on the ambulance if they knew
it was an ambulance used to carry yellow fever patients. “Well”,
he said, “we'll try not to let them know that that is the case”,
and he suggested that he leave the ambulance out in the weather
and I could pick it up and take it into my establishment and send
- 4 -
him another ambulance to take the place of it temporarily. This
I did. The result was that one ofter the other, the Wheelwright,
the blacksmith, the finisher, the painter, and the superintendent
of shops all went down with yellow fever, and all died.

In the meantime, Major Reed, at the head of the Board
that has made him his greatest fame, and all members of which be-
came famous, came to Havana for the purpose of investigating the
source and possible prevention of the disease. In my capacity of
Chief Quartermaster I set up his office, furnished it for him,
furnished him transportation, and built the small buildings in which
he carried out his investigations and experiments. I was in con-
stant contact with him. I had already known him when he came to
the Seventh Army Corps to amke the study of the typhoid epidemed,
when he headed the Board known as the Reed-Vaughn-S hakespeare
Board, and whose report is known to medical men throughout the
world for its scientific determination of the means by which that
diseases is carried.

Dr. Carlos Finley, an American physician who had
lived and practiced in Havana for many years, had advanced the
theory, with the result that by the end of the year 1900 he had
conclusively shown, together with the other members of his Board
consisting of Majors Carroll, Lazear and Agramonte, that the mos-
quito was the guilty party in the dessemination of this dread
disease. The methods by which he arrived at this conclusion are
well known to the medical profession and the details of the small
buildings which he used in determining this, are also well known.

Each one was divided into three compartments. The sub-
ject would enter the first compartment after having all mosquitoes
carefully driven away, remove his clothing, enter the next compart-
ment and clothe himself in sleeping garments, and from there he
would enter his sleeping apartment where he remained during the
perion of the experiment. In order to test the possibility of the
communication of this disease by direct contact or contamination,
the garments and bedding in which patients had died of the disease
were placed in the sleeping compartment of one of these buildings.
In no case was yellow fever contracted by this means.

In order to satisfy the Board, infected mosquitoes
were bottled up and after the subject had entered his sleeping
compartment were permitted to bite him. In some instances yellow
fever resulted, in others there was no result. By continued
experiment it was found that only a certain breed of mosquito
communicated the disease and eventually it was discovered that only
the female of that breed was guilty. With further experimentation
it was found that even she was not always capable of transmitting
the disease. To make the transmission effective, it was necessary
that the mosquito bite a patient suffering from the malady and at
a particular stage of development, and in communicating it, it
was necessary that the mosquito bite the victim at a certain time
-5-
(about five days) after having bitten an infected person. The
result of this was that after less than six months of experiment-
ation, Walter Reed was able to publish his findings, to the effect
that the disease is carried by nothing else but the mosquito, and
one breed of mosquito, and only the female of that breed, at a cer-
tain stage after having bitten a yellow fever patient.

Both Dr. Lazear and Major Carrloo submitted themselves
to this test. Lazear, as everyone knows, was so infortunate as to
die in this experiment. Carroll recovered but was never an entirely
well man afterward. Practically all members of the Hospital Corps
on duty at that time at Camp Columbis in Marianao most heroically
submitted themselves for this tset. Fortunately, none of these
men died. It was my pleasure, not long ago, to witness the placing
of medals on the breasts of two of the survivors, after a period of
something more than thirty years after the occurrence.

Major Reed became very much interested in my personal
experience in connection with the disease and was rather curious as
to why I had not been taken down with the disease, having been
constantly living in the same conditions that so many others had
lived and had been stricken--- in the mess and in my office and in
the carral. It could easily be understood that the mosquito was
the guilty party, but it could not be understood why the mosquitoes
would not bite me as well as all of those others. He asked me
about my medical experience during the period when I had served
in Havana. I told him that I had been taken down with what the
attending surgeon called calentura, and was in bed for two days,
but continued to perform my duties from my sick-bed. He consulted
with the attending surgeon, Major Laine, and they arrived at the
conclusion that the fever I had had, which had been called calen-
tura, was in all probability a light case of yellow fever and had
not been discovered, which rendered me immune to the bites of the
mosquito.

One of the most interesting features of this final discovery is to
be found in the comparison with what was actually known of the dis-
ease before these experiments were undertaken. For example, in
cases it was found that the disease was curbed by prospective
victims seeking certain localities, usually dry and free of mos-
quitoes. In the City of Jacksonville the entire population maved
out into the sand-hills from the city and established themselves
in tents and temporary quarters. The men would habitually go in
- 6 -
to the city during the daytime to ordinary business, always return-
ing before nightfall to the sand-hills. In that way the disease
was finally obliterated without their knowledge of the reason why.

As a matter of fact, the yellow fever mosquito, as a
rule, does not go far away from her breeding place. She is not
active except in a dark or gloomy corner or room, aor after night-
fall. Another incident that had been noted and commented on was
that the disease might start on a street and continue until it
reached a high wall and ther it would be checked until something
happened and it would seem to jump the wall and go on down the
street. What happened was that the winds carried the infected
mosquitoes over the wall where they continued their depradations.
Another thing, it would go down one side ot the street and leave the
other side free of this dread disease, until all those conditions
would change and it would junp across the street and go down the
other side. This was puzzling, but after the detection of the
culprit it was easily explained. The winds would come right to
carry the mosquitoes over the walls where they would proceed in
their nefarious calling, or the winds would change and blow them
across the street and there the mosquitoes would start a new
center of infection. All of the phenomena that had been witnessed
and commented upon in connection with yellow fever before Walter
Reed's discovery, found a simple explanation as soon as he had
determined that the mosquito was the culprit. The room in which
our group held its luncheons was infested with mosquitoes which
evidently buzzed about in the cark corners, the room being ill-
lighted. The room in which the clerks worked on Major Cartwright's
papers was a dark room infested with mosquitoes. All of the employ-
ees at the shops slept in the same quarters, which were found to
be infested with mosquitoes. All of the members of the Reed Board
are now dead but they have left behind them their places in the his-
tory of medical discovery that will remain so long as the medical
profession exists.

I wish to add to this recital that it was of great in-
terest to me to find that General Yruby, now in command of the
Army Medical Center, Washington, D. C., of which Walter Reed
Hospital is a part, was a young officer of the Medical Corps
during the entire period of the first occupation. Truby was the
first medical officer to reach Havana. The Eighth and Tenth In-
fantry Regiments were on provost-martial duty in Havana until
August, 1899, when they maved to Camp Columbia. Reed came to Cuba
- 7 -
and was a close personal friend of his. He and the other members
of the Board, except Agramonte, accepted the invitaion to live
with the Medical Staff at the Hospital at the Camp. It was a
great satisfaction, in a recent period of hospitalization, to talk
with General Truby and crystallize my recollections aof the incid-
ents herein related.
